com.avaya.csta.terminal

Interface MediaControlListener

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.util.EventListener
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    MediaControlAdapter

    public interface MediaControlListener
extends java.util.EventListener
    Use MediaControlListener to learn about media events for a given device. Supported events include:
    • MediaStartEvent
    • MediaStopEvent
    Add a listener using addMediaControlListener to be notified of when a media RTP stream is connected (media started) or disconnected (media stopped). Remove the listener when it is no longer needed. Click here to learn more about how to use listeners to be notified of certain events and be able to act upon those events.

    IMPORTANT:

    1. To determine if media is connected to a new call, look for both a MediaStartEvent and a lit green call appearance lamp. Implement the lampUpdated method in PhysicalDeviceListener to be notified of the LampModeEvent that occurs when the associated call appearance lamp changes to green. If the application receives subsequent MediaStartEvents due to shuffling, there is no need to check the lamp again.
    2. Following the receipt of the initial MediaStartEvent that indicates media is connected, subsequent, multiple MediaStopEvent/MediaStartEvent pairs may be received for a single call due to the media being shuffled by Communication Manager.
    3. To determine when the call has ended, look for the MediaStopEvent and for the call appearance lamp to turn off. Use the LampModeEvent from PhysicalDeviceListener to determine when the lamp turns off.

    Note that not all of the parameters for any given event may be supported. In these cases, the event description will contain a table of the parameters that are supported.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void esigReceived(EsigEvent event)
      Not supported.

      Instead, use DataCollectionServices to receive out-of-band DTMF digits.
      void mediaStarted(MediaStartEvent event)
      Indicates when the far-end RTP parameters have changed and an RTP session has been established.
      void mediaStopped(MediaStopEvent event)
      Indicates when the far-end RTP parameters have changed to null and the RTP session has been disconnected.

    • Method Detail

      • mediaStarted

        void mediaStarted(MediaStartEvent event)
        Indicates when the far-end RTP parameters have changed and an RTP session has been established. The MediaStartEvent contains the new far-end RTP IP address/port information. Multiple MediaStartEvents may be received on a single call due to situations such as shuffling. See the MediaStartEvent request for more information.
        Parameters:
        event - indication of new far-end RTP parameters established for media portion of call. Use event.getDescriptor().getRemoteMediaInfo() to obtain the new RTP parameters.
        See Also:
        lampUpdated(), MediaDescriptor, MediaInfo

      • mediaStopped

        void mediaStopped(MediaStopEvent event)
        Indicates when the far-end RTP parameters have changed to null and the RTP session has been disconnected. Your application should immediately stop playing to the media stream or recording from the media stream. See the MediaStopEvent request for more information.
        Parameters:
        event - indication that media has stopped and the RTP parameters should no longer be used
        See Also:
        PhysicalDeviceListener.lampUpdated(LampModeEvent)

      • esigReceived

        void esigReceived(EsigEvent event)
        Not supported.

        Instead, use DataCollectionServices to receive out-of-band DTMF digits.
